subject: Re: I'm new.
msgSnippet: Hey Vin - I m not quite sure how I first heard of Quickscript, although it was certainly as a result of interest in Tokien leading me to an interest in
messageBody:
Hey Vin -

I'm not quite sure how I first heard of Quickscript, although it was certainly as a result of interest in Tokien leading me to an interest in Conlanging which somehow led to invented scripts.

As for February - funny you mention it. One of the things that led me to give up on Quickscript back then was that I wasn't sure if I should be writing things as I said them or as they "ought" to sound. To my (American) ears, many of the vowels seemed nearly identical and I became unsure of when I should use which, and suddenly writing just became too exhausting for me to bother anymore.

Nowadays I don't suppose I'd care as much, since I'm likely to be the only one reading what I write.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Vincent Reilly <vin.reilly@...> wrote:
>
> Due to my roundabout way of asking my question I fear that I have been
> misunderstood! I guess my question really should have been this: what
> was your path that brought you to Quickscript?
>
> I grew up surrounded by people who pronounced the second month of the
> year "Febuary". After I learned to read, I noticed that the word was not
> spelled that way, and even though it made me sound affected, I started
> pronouncing it the way it is written. There is the letter R, big as life
> for everyone to see, right there after the B in syllable two!
>
> The next stop was the appendices to "The Return of the King", where I
> was introduced to the J.R.R. Tolkien/Elvish system of writing and
> introduced to my eighth-grade self the idea of phonetic writing. I spent
> a lot of time learning how to write American English in Elvish /tengwar/.
>
> Eventually, from prowling around on websites such as "The Simplified
> Spelling Society" I found quickscript. I see this as the best attempt to
> make a useful, usable phonetic alphabet -- I could imagine writing a
> journal in it.
> On 9/8/2012 8:58 PM, Sid Tanaban wrote:
> > 1. Find an international dictionary and look it up!
> > 2. The English accent is quite variable as any international language
> > is. There is no right or wrong because Read Alphabet is really used
> > more for personal writing than for international purposes.
> > 3. Shaw's alphabet was used internationally for abut 17 years but Mr
> > Read realized it was not quickly understood when read but one could
> > write it quickly.
> > 4. Very few people are strict about writing the brief letters of
> > Shaw's or Read's alphabet. Letters may be ill-formed due to haste, etc.
> > 5. Finally, have you noticed that many dictionaries give two or more
> > pronunciations to so many English words? Why be perfectionistic about
> > it when the English language itself does not lend itself to perfectionism?
> >
> > ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> > *From:* Vincent Reilly <vin.reilly@...>
> > *To:* Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > *Sent:* Wednesday, September 5, 2012 4:35 AM
> > *Subject:* Re: [Read_Alphabet] I'm new.
> >
> > Ryan,
> > we are all kindred spirits on the Read Alphabet group on Yahoo. As
> > such, I'm curious to know the answer to the following question
> > from you and anyone on the group.
> >
> > In the Read Alphabet, how do you, personally, write the second
> > syllable of the word February? Do you use letters 2-25-40, or
> > 2-17-40? I pronounce it the way it is spelled. This makes me a
> > little peculiar, since most people say what they hear other people
> > say without regard to the spelling.
> > Vin
> > On 9/2/2012 10:19 PM, Ryan wrote:
> >> Hi everyone. I've just joined and am excited to find there are
> >> other people in the world interested in the Read Alphabet.
> >>
> >> I first heard of Quikscript back in the late 90's and early
> >> 2000's, and at the time I thought I was just about the only
> >> person interested. Just today someone mentioned Shaw and it got
> >> me thinking about Shavian and Quikscript, so I did a quick search
> >> and found this group.
> >>
> >> Back when I first heard about the alphabet I got pretty far in
> >> teaching myself to read and write, though I think I eventually
> >> gave up because I often had trouble with my vowels. It looks like
> >> this group has some pretty great resources available though, so
> >> hopefully I'll be able to pick it back up again.
> >>
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
